subject: Re: How many aspects a particular test method should test???
msgSnippet: Thanks Rob et al. in pointing me towards the unreachability of someParam++. Well as Rob said it that is the danger of using code to illustrate your point
messageBody:
Thanks Rob et al. in pointing me towards the unreachability of
someParam++. Well as Rob said it that is the danger of using code to
illustrate your point (seeking help in my case :-))

I guess I should have rather written that method somewhat like :

public int someEarlierParam;
public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException{
if(someParam!=1||someParam!=2)
throw invalidParamException

someParam++;
someEarlierParam += someParam;
}

As I take it from the replies, each different task carried out by a
method should be tested by a different test method ?? But I attempted
one test method to take care of several different tasks of a
particular method and found it working ok. I deliberately failed it
for one task at a time, and JUnit reported me precisely for which of
the task (I mean which of my assert's) the test method is failing.
If same thing can be accomplished both ways (writing separate test
methods as well as by writing a single one) then what is the advantage
of writing separate ones ???

Thanks.
Nitesh Maan

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Rob Biedenharn <Rob_Biedenharn@a...> wrote:
> At 9/13/2005 04:27 AM, you wrote:
> >On Sunday 11 September 2005 20:31, xll_ll_ll_ll_ll_llx wrote:
> > > Hi all,
> > > I am really really new with JUnit. Do excuse me if this question is
> > > too simple that it irritated you. OK so here is my confusion:
> > >
> > > The method I want to test is something like this:
> > >
> > > public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException
> > > {
> > > if(someParam!=1||someParam!=2)
> > > throw invalidParamException
> > >
> > > someParam++;
> > > }
> > >
> > > Now this method will test someParam passed to it and if it gets
stuck
> > > in the IF statement will throw exception else update someParam. Now
> > > what I wanna know is that the test method that I write to test a
> > > method like this should I be writing one test method that tests both
> > > whether exception is thrown correctly as well as someParam updated
> > > correctly. OR
> > > I should be writing one test method that tests for the exception and
> > > another that tests whether someParam is being updated appropriately.
> >
> >At least two methods.
> >
> >Note that the update to `someParam` is pointless in the code you
> >show. `someParam` is a local variable (specifically, an argument)
> >of primitive type (int); when someMethod exits, someParam evaporates.
> >
> >--
> >Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
> >Logic is rational /re/construction. Life is construction.
>
> I don't know why I didn't see it before (well, yes I do, I wasn't
> looking!), but the example method simplifies to:
> public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException {
> throw new invalidParamException();
> }
> So it's trivial to test! (Not to mention just plain trivial, but
that's
> the danger of trying to illustrate a point with "code". I'm sure
that if
> one were to attempt to write a test for some observable behavior in
place
> of the "someParam++;" (say, a call to some other method), even the
> original author would discover the problem with the condition as
written.
>
> The problem with this type of code and the lack of tests is when
someone
> changes the condition and the previously unreachable code (but not
> "unreachable" in a simple, static sense) can then be executed. I
know I've
> been bitten by that bug in the past.
>
